title: Martine McCutcheon reveals Love Actually Comic Relief details ahead of Hugh Grant reunion
text:
TV Martine McCutcheon reveals Love Actually Comic Relief details ahead of Hugh Grant reunion The Loose Women panelist played Natalie - who fell in love with the Prime Minister - in the original film Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Martine McCutcheon reveals details of Love Actually Comic Relief Share this video Get celebs   Thank you for subscribing!   
Love Actually fans have been getting very excited about the Comic Relief sequel that’s currently being filmed. 
And Martine McCutcheon has now revealed details about what’s going to happen for her character Natalie and her love interest The Prime Minister - who was played by Hugh Grant. 
Speaking on Loose Women, Martine said she and him are definitely both starring together. 
However, she’s not completely sure if they’ll still be together, as she’s not seen a script yet. Read More Martine McCutcheon has revealed details of the Love Actually sequel (Photo: ITV/Lorraine) She played Natalie opposite Hugh Grant's Prime Minister (Photo: Publicity Picture) But she's unsure if they'll still be together (Photo: ITV/Lorraine) 
She said: “I’m hoping me and Hugh are still together because we’re filming together. 
“I haven’t been sent a script, I’ve just been in wardrobe.” 
She went on to reveal what she hopes Natalie and the Prime Minister will now be up to. 
Martine said: “I really hope they’ve had a couple of kids and he’s still doing his silly dancing, and for him still to be in Downing Street. 
“I’m hoping the magic of it all comes back for something so lovely.” 
Martine and Hugh have stayed in touch since working together on the original film Love Actually in 2003. Read More She hopes they now have kids (Photo: ITV/Lorraine) She still speaks to Hugh (Photo: ITV/Lorraine) And she wouldn't have done the sequel without him (Photo: ITV/Lorraine) 
She said: “We have this banter. We’re so different, from such different backgrounds, but it’s why we work. 
“He has a go at me, I have a go at him. 
“He’s lovely, we still DM and text, but I’m so excited to work with him again. 
“I wouldn’t feel right doing it without Hugh.”
